lessons.title: What Lack I Yet?
topics: The rich young ruler and eternal life
The parable of the laborers in the vineyard
The first shall be last and the last first
suggested_questions: What does it mean to 'sell all that thou hast' in our modern lives? What are our equivalents?
How does the parable of the laborers in the vineyard challenge our sense of fairness?
What can we learn from the disciples' reaction when Jesus said it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle?
How do we become like little children while still handling adult responsibilities?
What does 'with God all things are possible' mean when we face our own 'what lack I yet' moments?

lessons.title: Thy King Cometh
topics: The parable of the two sons
The parable of the wicked husbandmen
suggested_questions: What does Jesus cleansing the temple teach us about what we should remove from our own lives?
In the parable of the two sons, which son do we most relate to, and why?
How do we 'render unto God the things that are God's' in our daily lives?
What does it mean to love God with all our heart, soul, and mind?
How can we better recognize and welcome the Savior's presence in our lives?

lessons.title: Of That Day and Hour Knoweth No Man
topics: The parable of the ten virgins
suggested_questions: How do we stay prepared without becoming anxious about the Second Coming?
What does the 'oil' in the parable of the ten virgins represent in our lives?
In the parable of the talents, what 'talents' has God given you, and how are you developing them?
What does the story of the widow's mite teach us about the quality of our offerings?
How does serving 'the least of these' become service to Christ?

lessons.title: This Do in Remembrance of Me
topics: The Last Supper and the sacrament
The new commandment to love one another
suggested_questions: How can we make our weekly sacrament experience more meaningful?
What does Jesus washing the disciples' feet teach us about leadership and service?
How do we live the 'new commandment' to love one another as Christ has loved us?
What can we learn from Peter's overconfidence and subsequent denial?
How does understanding Gethsemane change how we approach our own suffering?
